title: Emergency Kit Essentials: Your Lifeline in Crisis
description: A well-stocked emergency kit is crucial for survival when disaster strikes. Learn what supplies to gather, how to maintain your kit, and where to store emergency supplies to be prepared for any situation.

sections.title: Basic Disaster Supplies Kit
sections.content:
Your basic emergency supply kit should be stored in airtight plastic bags and placed in one or two easy-to-carry containers such as plastic bins or a duffel bag. Include these essential items:

- **Water**: One gallon per person per day for several days, for drinking and sanitation
- **Food**: At least a several-day supply of non-perishable food
- **Battery-powered or hand crank radio** and a NOAA Weather Radio with tone alert
- **Flashlight** with extra batteries
- **First aid kit**
- **Whistle** to signal for help
- **Dust mask** to help filter contaminated air
- **Plastic sheeting, scissors and duct tape** for sheltering in place
- **Moist towelettes, garbage bags and plastic ties** for personal sanitation
- **Wrench or pliers** to turn off utilities
- **Manual can opener** for food
- **Local maps** for navigation
- **Cell phone with chargers and a backup battery**

sections.title: Additional Emergency Supplies
sections.content:
Consider adding these items to your emergency kit based on your household's specific needs:

- **Cleaning supplies**: Soap, hand sanitizer and disinfecting wipes
- **Medications**: Prescription medications (half of all Americans take daily prescription medicine)
- **Over-the-counter medications**: Pain relievers, anti-diarrhea medication, antacids or laxatives
- **Vision needs**: Prescription eyeglasses and contact lens solution
- **Baby supplies**: Infant formula, bottles, diapers, wipes and diaper rash cream
- **Pet supplies**: Pet food and extra water for your pet
- **Financial resources**: Cash or traveler's checks
- **Documents**: Important family documents such as copies of insurance policies, identification and bank account records (saved electronically or in a waterproof, portable container)
- **Bedding**: Sleeping bag or warm blanket for each person
- **Clothing**: Complete change of clothing appropriate for your climate and sturdy shoes
- **Fire safety**: Fire extinguisher
- **Emergency lighting**: Matches in a waterproof container
- **Personal items**: Feminine supplies and personal hygiene items
- **Kitchen supplies**: Mess kits, paper cups, plates, paper towels and plastic utensils
- **Communication tools**: Paper and pencil
- **Entertainment**: Books, games, puzzles or other activities for children

sections.title: Maintaining Your Kit
sections.content:
An emergency kit is only effective if it's properly maintained and ready when needed:

- Keep canned food in a cool, dry place
- Store boxed food in tightly closed plastic or metal containers
- Replace expired items as needed
- Re-think your needs every year and update your kit as your family's needs change

Consider setting calendar reminders to check your kit every six months. This is also a good time to check smoke detector batteries and review your family emergency plan.

sections.title: Kit Storage Locations
sections.content:
Since emergencies can happen anywhere at any time, prepare supplies for multiple locations:

- **Home Kit**: Keep this in a designated place and have it ready in case you have to leave your home quickly. Make sure all family members know where the kit is kept.

- **Work Kit**: Be prepared to shelter at work for at least 24 hours. Your work kit should include food, water and other necessities like medicines, as well as comfortable walking shoes, stored in a "grab and go" case.

- **Car Kit**: In case you are stranded, keep a kit of emergency supplies in your car. This is especially important during winter months when travel can be hazardous.

Each kit may contain different items based on the location and potential emergencies you might face in that environment.

sections.title: Special Considerations
sections.content:
Different household members may have unique needs to consider when building your emergency kit:

- **Children**: Include comfort items, activities, and familiar snacks

- **Seniors**: Consider medical devices, mobility aids, and any special dietary requirements

- **People with disabilities**: Include necessary assistive technologies, extra medication, and instructions for medical equipment

- **Pets and service animals**: Have leashes, carriers, food, water, bowls, and documentation

Think about your family's specific requirements and add items that address their individual needs.

sections.title: Low-Cost Preparedness
sections.content:
Building an emergency kit doesn't have to be expensive. Here are some budget-friendly tips:

- Start small and build your kit over time
- Purchase items when they're on sale
- Use containers you already have at home
- Check dollar stores for supplies like flashlights, batteries, and first aid items
- Rotate food from your regular pantry into your emergency supplies
- Share bulk purchases with friends or family members also building kits

Remember, having some supplies is better than none. Even a partial kit will be valuable during an emergency.
